results.notes:
I find the smooth surface unlike the description, but perhaps I found these early?

Interesting story with this I spent four hours hiking up onto and along a mountain ridge (that begins at Blue Mountain ski resort and ends at Palmerton Gap via the Appalachian Trail) which includes a road for reforestation efforts. The first half of the road is through thick and varied forest, but the other half is area that had been industrially cleared as part of zinc mining. The landscape is shrubs with plenty of grass and small trees. Lots of scattered rocks. It’s clear the area is recovering both naturally (and with purposeful reforestation). The first half I found many and varied species of fungi, but the latter half I found just a few fungi and of only two saprophyte species. I can easily guess that the diversity will be gained after much time.

Pileus (3)6–7(9) cm broad, convex to plano-convex, glutinous-viscid at first, soon drying, greenish-olive (4E–F8,7,6,5 to 4D5) to grayish-green (30C4), fading and becoming mustard brown (5E7,6,5), heavily matted tomentose to matted subvelutinous under gluten, more obvious when drying out, with sterile appendiculate marginal veil when young, collapsing and shrinking at pileus margin with age. Flesh white, unchanging, with mild odor and mild to bitter taste. Tubes adnexed, whitish at first, becoming pinkish vinaceous (7C3), with pores concolorous and bruising somewhat brownish. Stipe (4.5)5–6(10.5) cm long, 1–2(3) cm broad, equal, or rarely with a slightly broader base, strict or curved, dry but sometimes with some glutinous veil remnants, white with a dark brown to cinnamon brown to pale brown sublacunose or coarse reticulum, sometimes discoloring brownish with injury, white at base with white rhizomorphs.
results.location_name: Ben Bennett Bushland Reserve, Caloundra, Queensland, Australia

results.notes: Pileus 3-5 cm broad, convex to plane, viscid-glutinous, appearing suede-like under the gluten at first, then with plaque-like, flattened scales with age, whitish with obvious pale pink tinges, with white appendiculate veil remnants at margin. Flesh white, unchanging with mild odor and bitter taste. Tubes adnexed, whitish at first, becoming vinaceous pink, with pores whitish at first becoming vinaceous pink, unchanging. Stipe 7-8 cm long, 5-7 mm broad, equal with a slightly broader base, lacunose-reticulate to coarsely lacunose, white, somewhat sticky, with interior pithy, white, unchanging, with white rhizomorphs at base. Spores amygdaliform, coarsely and variously ornamented around the middle.

results.notes:
One of the specimens seen/collected by me at NEMF’s foray #11. Mixed woods of hemlock and hardwoods (birch, beech, maple). Pretty certain this is what Peck collected near Caroga Lake and called B. subvelutipes.
There were many, many examples of this taxon brought by participants to the sorting tables from almost all forays, and they pretty much looked like this one with some expected variation in the colors of the cap and stipe; however, some looked more what we used to call “discolor” with yellow/orange caps. Still, I continue to believe that the oak-loving entity I collect in NJ is sufficiently different from this hemlock-associated type (http://mushroomobserver.org/observer/advanced_search?q=8DR8) to suspect another species rather than phenotypic clinal variation. Well, I will find out soon enough.

In birch -spruce forest.

This was the first of four specimens found within an area of about 4 acres, just to the north of (West) Caroga Lake. The area was a hemlock forest on a slightly elevated area in view of the lake. A few birch trees were present. No oak in this area.

This single specimen, labeled “A” in the series of photos. is post-mature and fairly slug-eaten. Although I was initially thrilled to see it, the subsequent specimens featured much sharped macro-traits.

For this specimen:
Cap burnt orange to rusty orange staining black, subtomentose to minutely bumpy. Margin inrolled a few millimeters.
Stipe surface difficult to determine due to insect damage, a mix of dark red and dingy yellowish, with the lower third predominantly red. Ridges near insect damage darkened. No hairs observed on the base.
Pore surface red.

Preserved for study. Material passed along to Igor Safonov.

- The stem can grow up to 4-5 inches
- the cap can be more than 1 inch in dia.
- the cap is brown when it’s very young then it changes to white and as it grow older it looks white mixed with grey
- the gills look brown
- there is no special odor for this kind ( I couldn’t smell anything )

results.notes: Collected during an NJMA foray at this park by Edward Zeme, a new member of the club. Of all the folks who hit the woods, Ed got lucky and hit this jackpot (IMO this is the foray’s most prized collection, but then I am very partial to fleshy pored mushrooms). Call it beginner’s luck, but there were many beginners at this foray. :-) Ed navigated a treacherous terrain (a very steep and rocky slope) to collect these (several large, mature and somewhat waterlogged fruitbodies). They were growing in abundance on ground amidst some leaf-covered rocks in deciduous woods. Fairly soft, yellow to yellow-brown zonate caps with a wavy margin, staining bluish-green here and there; mustard-yellow, large pores with a very jagged/uneven edge (the color looks more brown in the pix).
results.location_name: Stephens State Park, Warren Co., New Jersey, USA

results.notes:
These are the second and third of four specimens found within an area of about 4 acres, just to the north of (West) Caroga Lake. The area was a hemlock forest on a slightly elevated area in view of the lake. A few birch trees were present. No oak in this area. These two mushrooms were growing a few inches apart.

The larger of these two specimens was the one sectioned and subjected to chemicals. The remaining half is preserved and packaged along with the other smaller one. The bag and the photos are labeled “B”. There was some insect damage, but not enough to prevent observation of key macro-traits, in particular the hairy stipe bases.

Found within 50 yards of obs 285175. Collected during a predominantly wet spell of weather.

Cap surface pale orange to reddish orange bruising black, glabrous to slightly subtomentose to minutely bumpy.
Largest arc along cap surfaces ~3 cm and ~5-6 cm respectively.
Stipe lengths ~5 cm and ~7 cm respectively.
Stipe surface basically glabrous and a vertically mottled mix of red, yellow, and whitish along the middle 75%. Punctate toward the apex with dots reddish to brownish. Base fuzzy with dark red areas intermingled with yellow areas.
Pore surface red but paler and tending toward yellow near the margin, bruising black.
Sterile margin 1-2 millimeters wide.
Tubes yellow bruising blue, but not strongly.
Cap context pale yellow, staining blue when sliced and then appearing whitish beneath the stain.
Stipe context lemon-yellow staining blue when sliced. Red in extreme base. Insect tunnels red to blackish.

KOH: scarlet on cap surface, rusty orange on context.
Ammonia: dirty orangish to olivaceous on cap surface, yellowish to orangish on context.

results.notes:
5-Aug-17: A single mature/post-mature fruitbody growing on dead/decaying wood in deciduous woods.
The dark olive-brown cap with red-cracks is more in line with Xerocomellus chrysenteron, but the stipe is not consistent with that taxon (mostly yellow and scruffy above with a red lower portion/base). The fact that it’s growing on wood could be just a coincidence, so I don’t think this is Boletellus chrysenteroides just because of the substrate. The morphology is not consistent with chrysenteroides, but the fb is old, so it’s still a possibility.
Further input is solicited from anyone who has good ideas about the identity of this bolete.
I saved this collection and meant to take it home, but instead left it inadvertently with the Burghardts.
7-Aug-17: the dried material is in my possession.
21-Aug-17: Here is the measurement of 10 spores – (10.7-) 11.6 – 14.0 (-14.4) x 5.1 – 5.6 um. Spore pic posted below.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (last revised on 12-Jul-22):
> This collection was sample for nrITS by Dr. Kudzma.
The raw chromatograms revealed that there are 3 points of heterogeneity: one in ITS1 sublocus and two in ITS2 sublocus. Careful analysis of the data allowed me to conclude that there are only two haplotypes involved (in ~2.2:1 ratio by area under the curve) and to proceed with a manual resolution of the haplotypes and the derivation of their full-length ITS sequences.
> The overall heterogeneity pattern presented by this organism is a curious one. First, the major haplotype inserts an extra “T” in ITS1 (1st 1-base-shift), but then loses a “G” in early ITS2 (2nd 1-base-shift) relative to the minor one that has 2 "G"s in a row. From this point on the two halotypes overlap perfectly because the chromatogram is a single set of peaks again. Then, at the very end of ITS2, just 25 characters before the start of nrLSU region, the minor haplotype inserts an extra “A” (for 3 "A"’s in a row). Hence, the full-length of ITS of Hap-1 is 665 bps long and that of Hap-2 is 666 bps long. The heterogeneity also allowed for the resolution of two ambiguous positions located in the region between the first two points of heterogeneity. Fig. A shows the alignment of the two haplotypes and highlights the differences between them. Removal of the gaps from the alignment will reproduced the pattern of peaks seen in the chromatograms. Because of the 5 mismatching positions (including the gaps), the two haplotypes have a genetic distance of 0.75% relative to each other.
> The derived sequences are 99.55% and 98.80% similar to accession MW882071 associated with my obs 327809. See the latter post for more details. There is no question about the conspecificity of these collections as far as ITS is concerned, but note the morphological and ecological differences between them. The ITS1 region of Hap-1 is a 99.4-100% match (71-100% query cover) to 5 accessions of Xerocomellus truncatus from the study by Frank et al. (2020).1 That and the characteristic spores with truncate-applanate apices support the X. truncatus ID for this collection.
Reference:
1 Frank et al., “Xerocomellus (Boletaceae) in Western North America”; Fungal Systematics and Evolution 6: pp. 65–288 (2020). Free access at https://www.researchgate.net/....

The specimen is about 12-14 inches wide and about 3-4 inches thick. it is growing from the base and apex of the trunk on an ornamental plum tree. Its colors range from dull burgundy red to vanished orange across the pileus. Its pore surface is white with small tightly spaced pores. It was firm but almost malleable when squeezed. I will attempt to retrieve a spore sample for microscopy tomorrow. At first I thought it was G. oregonense, but upon further thought I don’t believe G. oregonense grows on plum. It may possibly be G. lucidum.
Update: Spores are 10.3 × 7.4 um smooth and ovoid in shape.
Update 8/13: KOH indicator test resulted in darkening on all surfaces to almost black. A cross section of the specimen shows white striations on a predominantly brown internal surface.

results.notes: Found in Beech forest, some maple, and ash. Does not bruise. Stem appears to have a violet hue.

About two years ago I posted an observation (term 203720) of P. cinnabarinus found on a fallen branch. I brought the branch home and put it on the window sill in my garage. Last spring when I cleaned out the garage I threw the branch into my garden to see what, if anything, would develop. This observation shows the development of more cinnabarinus specimens as they progress from their first emergence through the bark to development of the characteristic caps with their tiny orange-red pores. Seeing the way this specimen evolved through its various stages of growth was an interesting treat for me, and surely is a testament to the long-term viability of spores … just waiting for the right conditions to fruit again. The last photo is a collage of two pictures from the 2015 observation showing the fully developed specimens.

Habitat: mixed wood, Fagus sylvatica dominant tree following by Picea abies; slightly inclined mountain slope, southeast aspect, old colluvial, calcareous, skeletal ground; in shade; relatively warm and dry place; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies, average precipitation ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 570 m (1.870 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: old, cut off, standing trunk of Fagus sylvatica, partly debarked.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, next to the trail from Trenta 2b cottage to Strgulc abandoned farm house, Soča 48, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Stemonitis lignicola is generally considered a quite rare species. However, all macro and micro traits of this find as well as substratum fit well to Stemonitis lignicola descriptions in literature. An exception may be slightly large spores. However, the observed differences in diameter are roughly of the same size as between an example shown in Ref. 3 compared to average given in Ref.: 2. Capillitium extensions (resembling warts or free ends) were found rare and small. Note that Ref: 2 doesn’t mention capillitium extensions at all and talks about smooth capilitial threads, while Ref.: 5 claims presence of capillitium extensions for this species.

Sporocarps cylindrical, somewhat curved, about 12 mm high and 0.35-0.45 mm in diameter, stalks 2.5-3 mm long; surface capilitial net distinctive, uniform, small meshed, with rare extensions; capilitial internal net sparse, thick, with some membranous expansions; columella reaching the tip of sporocarps, gradually tapering toward the top, frequently bended in the upper part of the sporocarp; stalks short, blackish brown to black, shiny; hypothallus membranous, shiny; plasmodium white; spores on mass abundant, dark brown.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Sony ILCE6000 / Carl Zeiss Vario-Tessar E 16-70mm/ f4
